name: weaned calves production on pasture | cattle for slaughtering, live weight | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/19975/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of live weight of weaned calves for beef production in South Africa. The weaned calves are sold at seven months old, predominantly to feedlots for fattening. Feedlots account for the majority of beef produced in South Africa (65-75%, with free-range beef accounting for less than 5%, and the balance supplied by lower-grade beef from culled dairy and breeding cattle). In this dataset, weaned calves are the primary product, with culled breeding cattle and excess heifers considered by-products. A breeding cycle is considered to be one year (i.e. one year of breeding herd is required to produce the weaners). A portion of the female calves are retained to replace the culled cows, with an average herd replacement rate of of circa 16% applied in the dataset. Excess heifers are female calves raised to one year, but that do not calve, and are subsequently sold (primarily to feedlots).;Direct emissions from the cattle (enteric methane), as well as direct and indirect emissions from manure (ammonia, nitrous oxide and methane), are calculated using best available methods (IPCC) with regional adaptations. All manure is deposited on pasture and is not collected (i.e. cattle manure as an organic fertiliser of the pasture is only accounted for in terms of field emissions). Cattle are predominantly raised on natural pasture, thus there is no irrigation nor fertiliser, seed etc. included in the dataset. Emissions of heavy metals to soil and surface water estimated from manure left on pasture during grazing is after Nemecek and Schnetzer (2012). The factors applied in the equations are not South African specific and the calculated emissions are thus highly uncertain (especially leached emissions where South African conditions are likely to be very different).  

This activity starts at the start of the cattle breeding season.

This activity ends with the provision of weaned calves at the farm gate, ready to be sold for finishing at feedlots, as live weight. Culled breeding cattle and excess heifers are produced as by-products. Emissions from cattle and field emissions are included, as are their requirements (feed supplements and water). Pasture is natural, thus minimal maintenance is assumed to be required (some tractor and trailer use is included, but no fertiliser, seed etc.).
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/014:Animal production/0141:Raising of cattle and buffaloes

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: South African values: Not applicable worldwide.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Data and assumptions reflect current farming practices in South Africa
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data from six sample farms provide the majority of activity data for the dataset. However, where more representative data are avaialable (such as emission factors for methane and nitrous oxide developed for South Africa's national greenhouse gas inventory) these are applied instead. Other literature, national statistics, and discussions with industry experts are used to fill various data gaps. Emissions of phosphates and heavy metals from manure are estimated according to Nemecek and Schnetzer (2011).

exchanges.description: Cows that fail to conceive are replaced with retained heifers and sold for slaughter. Herd replacement varied from 9% to 26%, depending on the farm, with a rate of 15.8% applied to those farms that did not provide data on numbers of heifers retained (applying a literature conception rate of 85% (Banga et al., 2014) and assuming all cows that do not conceive are culled). The cow is assumed to have a live weight of 450-500kg (depending on the farm/breed) when it leaves the farm to be slaughtered. Reference(s): Banga C.B, Neser F.W.C. and Garrick D.J. (2014) Breeding Objectives for Holstein cattle in South Africa, South African Journal of Animal Science, Volume 44 (3), pp. 199-214

flow.name: cattle for slaughtering, live weight
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/014:Animal production/0141:Raising of cattle and buffaloes

exchanges.description: The exchange has been updated from 'urea, as N' into 'urea' and therefore its amount has been scaled (multiplied) from 0.1246 kg by 2.1438 kg of 'urea' per kg of 'urea, as N'. Original comment of the exchange is: Component of feed supplement. Feed supplementation required by cattle taken from requirements for farming in the KwaZulu-Natal region of South Africa (industry data), with few natural pastures in South Africa of sufficient quality to support year-round grazing. Supplementation changes with the season (typically winter and summer) and amounts required differ with animal type (herd broken down into weaners, cows and bulls). Farmers either purchase pre-mixed supplements and licks, or make up their own. Supplements are predominantly salt, urea and a roughage component (bagasse or maize). For the roughage component, some farmers use brown grass or silage saved over from the good season. The composition of mineral licks and pre-mixed supplements was provided by various farmers and suppliers in the region.

flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2012:Manufacture of fertilizers and nitrogen compounds

defaultProvider.name: market for urea | urea | Cutoff, U
defaultProvider.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2012:Manufacture of fertilizers and nitrogen compounds

exchanges.description: Emissions of heavy metals to soil and surface water estimated from manure left on pasture during grazing based on Nemecek and Schnetzer (2012). The factors applied in the equations are not South African specific and the calculated emissions are thus highly uncertain (especially leached emissions where South African conditions are likely to be very different).  A manure generation rate of 1.82 tonnes/(head.year) for commercial cattle in field is applied in the dataset (DEA, 2017). As the pasture is natural, there are no associated fertiliser, seed and pesticide applications. There is however removal of biomass through grazing. Reference(s): Nemecek and Schnetzer (2012) Methods of Assessment of Direct Field Emissions for LCIs of Agricultural Production Systems, Life cycle inventories of Swiss and European agricultural production systems. Reference(s): DEA (2017) Unlocking Barriers and Opportunities for Land-use Based Climate-Change Mitigation Activities in South Africa, Department of Environmental Affairs of South Africa, Available at: https://www.environment.gov.za/sites/default/files/reports/unlockingbarriers_land-usebasedclimatechangemitigation.pdf. (Accessed September 2017),

Natural pasture for grazing. Stocking rate reported by farms varied from 3.0 to 11 hectares per live unit (adult herd excluding calved), with an average value of 5.1 ha/live unit. Beef farming occurs predominantly in the grassland regions of SA, so this is taken as the pre-farming land use.

flow.name: Transformation, from grassland, natural, for livestock grazing

exchanges.description: Component of feed supplement. Feed supplementation required by cattle taken from requirements for farming in the KwaZulu-Natal region of South Africa (industry data), with most natural pastures in South Africa of insufficient quality to support year-round grazing. Supplementation changes with the season (typically winter and summer) and amounts required differ with animal type (herd broken down into weaners, cows and bulls). Farmers either purchase pre-mixed supplements and licks, or make up their own. Supplements are predominantly salt, urea and a roughage component (bagasse or maize). For the roughage component, some farmers use brown grass or silage saved over from the good season. The composition of mineral licks and pre-mixed supplements was provided by various farmers and suppliers in the region.

exchanges.description: Emissions of phosphorous through soil erosion is from Nemecek and Schnetzer (2012). The factors applied in the equations are not South African specific and the calculated emissions are thus highly uncertain.  A manure generation rate of 1.82 tonnes/(head.year) for commercial cattle in field is applied in the dataset (DEA, 2017). As the pasture is natural there are no associated fertiliser applications. Reference(s): Nemecek and Schnetzer (2012) Methods of Assessment of Direct Field Emissions for LCIs of Agricultural Production Systems, Life cycle inventories of Swiss and European agricultural production systems. Reference(s): DEA (2017) Unlocking Barriers and Opportunities for Land-use Based Climate-Change Mitigation Activities in South Africa, Department of Environmental Affairs of South Africa, Available at: https://www.environment.gov.za/sites/default/files/reports/unlockingbarriers_land-usebasedclimatechangemitigation.pdf. (Accessed September 2017)

A manure generation rate of 1.82 tonnes/(head.year) for commercial cattle in field is applied in the dataset (DEA, 2017). As the pasture is natural, there are no associated fertiliser, seed and pesticide applications. There is however removal of biomass through grazing. Methane from enteric fermentation and manure management.  Emission factor per animal (bull, calving cows, oxen and calves), taking into account field types and digestibilities, pasture feed characteristics, and livestock weight and weight gain, from du Toit et al., (2013). Herd composition from six sample farms. Reference: du Toit C.J.L., Meissner H.H. and van Niekerk W.A. (2013) Direct Methane and Nitrous Oxide Emissions of South African Dairy and Beef Cattle, South African Journal of Animal Science, Volume 43 (3), pp 320-339

Drinking water for cattle. The daily water requirement for cattle varied from 30 to 95 litres/head/day depending on the farm (average of 54 litres/head/day). Water is sourced from rivers, farm dams or boreholes, depending on the region.

Emissions of phosphates through run-off from manure deposited on pasture is from on Nemecek and Schnetzer (2012). The factors applied in the equations are not South African specific and the calculated emissions are thus highly uncertain (especially run-off emissions where South African conditions are likely to be very different).  A manure generation rate of 1.82 tonnes/(head.year) for commercial cattle in field is applied in the dataset (DEA, 2017). As the pasture is natural there are no associated fertiliser applications. Reference(s): Nemecek and Schnetzer (2012) Methods of Assessment of Direct Field Emissions for LCIs of Agricultural Production Systems, Life cycle inventories of Swiss and European agricultural production systems. Reference(s): DEA (2017) Unlocking Barriers and Opportunities for Land-use Based Climate-Change Mitigation Activities in South Africa, Department of Environmental Affairs of South Africa, Available at: https://www.environment.gov.za/sites/default/files/reports/unlockingbarriers_land-usebasedclimatechangemitigation.pdf. exchanges.description: Emissions of heavy metals to soil and surface water estimated from manure left on pasture during grazing based on Nemecek and Schnetzer (2012). The factors applied in the equations are not South African specific and the calculated emissions are thus highly uncertain (especially leached emissions where South African conditions are likely to be very different).  A manure generation rate of 1.82 tonnes/(head.year) for commercial cattle in field is applied in the dataset (DEA, 2017). As the pasture is natural, there are no associated fertiliser, seed and pesticide applications. There is however removal of biomass through grazing. Reference(s): Nemecek and Schnetzer (2012) Methods of Assessment of Direct Field Emissions for LCIs of Agricultural Production Systems, Life cycle inventories of Swiss and European agricultural production systems. Reference(s): DEA (2017) Unlocking Barriers and Opportunities for Land-use Based Climate-Change Mitigation Activities in South Africa, Department of Environmental Affairs of South Africa, Available at: https://www.environment.gov.za/sites/default/files/reports/unlockingbarriers_land-usebasedclimatechangemitigation.pdf. (Accessed September 2017),

Ammonia emissions from manure left in field during grazing. Calculations following the IPCC guidelines using a combination of default IPCC and country specific input values. Emission factor per animal (bull, calving cows, oxen and calves), taking into account field types and digestibilities, pasture feed characteristics, and livestock weight and weight gain, from du Toit et al., (2013). Herd composition from six sample farms. Weaners are on pasture for 7 months, whilst 12 months of breeding cattle are required to complete a breeding cycle. Reference(s): IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories‚ Prepared by the National Greenhouse Gas Inventories Programme‚ IGES, Japan; du Toit C.J.L., Meissner H.H. and van Niekerk W.A. (2013) Direct Methane and Nitrous Oxide Emissions of South African Dairy and Beef Cattle, South African Journal of Animal Science, Volume 43 (3), pp 320-339

flow.name: Transformation, to grassland, natural, for livestock grazing

exchanges.description: There is no cultivation as the pasture for grazing is natural. Diesel use on the farm is thus for general production activities, such as maintenance, feeding and fence checking. It is assumed that the field work is carried out in a tractor and trailer. Diesel consumption on the farm is estimated at 4,000 litres per year. The equivalent tonnes.km were calculated using the diesel consumption of the dataset: transport, tractor and trailer, agricultural (43.6g diesel/tonne*km)

exchanges.description: Component of feed supplement (substrate). The substrate is typically sugar cane bagasse and/or molasses. As neither of these substances are in the ecoinvent database, sugar beet molasses is used as an approximation. Feed supplementation required by cattle taken from requirements for farming in the KwaZulu-Natal region of South Africa (industry data), with most natural pastures in South Africa of insufficient quality to support year-round grazing. Supplementation changes with the season (typically winter and summer) and amounts required differ with animal type (herd broken down into weaners, cows and bulls). Farmers either purchase pre-mixed supplements and licks, or make up their own. Supplements are predominantly salt, urea and a roughage component (bagasse or maize). For the roughage component, some farmers use brown grass or silage saved over from the good season. The composition of mineral licks and pre-mixed supplements was provided by various farmers and suppliers in the region.

exchanges.description: Natural pasture for grazing. Stocking rate reported by farms varied from 3.0 to 11 hectares per live unit (adult herd excluding calved), with an average value of 5.1 ha/live unit. Beef farming occurs predominantly in the grassland regions of SA, so this is taken as the pre-farming land use. A nominal farm life of 30 years is assumed.

Emission factor per animal (bull, calving cows, oxen and calves), taking into account field types and digestibilities, pasture feed characteristics, and livestock weight and weight gain, from du Toit et al., (2013). Herd composition from six sample farms. Indirect N2O includes only that from deposition of N following volatilisation as ammonia and nitrates, i.e. does not include that from leaching or run-off of N, as this is assumed to be zero (no irrigation and grazing in generally dry areas). Reference(s): IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories‚ Prepared by the National Greenhouse Gas Inventories Programme‚ IGES, Japan; du Toit C.J.L., Meissner H.H. and van Niekerk W.A. (2013) Direct Methane and Nitrous Oxide Emissions of South African Dairy and Beef Cattle, South African Journal of Animal Science, Volume 43 (3), pp 320-339

flow.name: Dinitrogen monoxide
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density
